questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about ZF and MMSE?

answers.b: MMSE and ZF perform equally at high noise
answers.c: MMSE performs better than ZF at low SNR
answers.d: MMSE is a linear approximation of ZF

explanations.a: Incorrect. ZF does not always outperform MMSE; MMSE can outperform ZF especially at low SNR.
explanations.b: Incorrect. MMSE and ZF perform similarly at high SNR, not high noise.
explanations.c: Correct. MMSE accounts for noise and generally performs better than ZF at low SNR.
explanations.d: Incorrect. MMSE is not a linear approximation of ZF.

questions.question: What is the major drawback of the Zero Forcing (ZF) equalizer?

answers.b: It amplifies noise in channels with deep fades or low singular values
answers.d: It does not work with MIMO systems

explanations.a: Incorrect. Both ZF and MMSE require channel knowledge.
explanations.b: Correct. ZF can significantly amplify noise especially in channels with low singular values.
explanations.c: Incorrect. ZF is computationally simpler than some other equalizers like ML.
explanations.d: Incorrect. ZF is commonly used in MIMO systems.

questions.question: Which equalizer is computationally simpler but less robust to noise?

explanations.a: Incorrect. MMSE is more complex but more robust to noise.
explanations.b: Correct. ZF is simpler but amplifies noise in poor channel conditions.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Maximum Likelihood detection is computationally intensive.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Sphere Decoder is a near-ML method and computationally demanding.

questions.question: The MMSE equalizer reduces to the Zero Forcing equalizer in which case?

explanations.a: Incorrect. At high noise, MMSE and ZF differ significantly.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Signal power level alone doesn't cause MMSE to reduce to ZF.
explanations.c: Correct. As noise approaches zero, MMSE converges to ZF solution.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Bandwidth does not affect this relationship.

questions.question: What is the effect of MMSE regularization compared to ZF?

answers.a: It reduces inter-symbol interference but increases complexity
answers.b: It adds a noise-dependent regularization term to reduce noise amplification
answers.d: It increases the condition number of the matrix

explanations.a: Incorrect. Both MMSE and ZF address interference, but MMSE specifically regularizes to reduce noise amplification.
explanations.b: Correct. MMSE adds a regularization term dependent on noise variance to mitigate noise amplification.
explanations.c: Incorrect. MMSE explicitly uses the channel matrix.
explanations.d: Incorrect. MMSE improves conditioning by regularization.

questions.question: Which matrix operation is used in the ZF equalizer for a MIMO channel with matrix Hᴴ?

explanations.a: Incorrect. This is just the Hermitian, not the full ZF equalizer.
explanations.b: Correct. ZF uses the pseudo-inverse: (Hᴴ H)⁻¹ Hᴴ.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This is not the ZF equalizer operation.
explanations.d: Incorrect. H may not be square or invertible.

questions.question: In a system where H is the channel matrix and σ² is the noise variance, what is the MMSE equalizer matrix?

explanations.a: Incorrect. H may not be invertible and this ignores noise.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This is the ZF equalizer.
explanations.c: Correct. MMSE equalizer is (Hᴴ H + σ² I)⁻¹ Hᴴ, accounting for noise.
explanations.d: Incorrect. This is not the standard MMSE formula.

questions.question: What happens when the MIMO channel matrix Hᴴ is not full-rank?

answers.b: MMSE and ZF perform the same
answers.c: ZF becomes ill-conditioned and performs poorly
answers.d: Both ZF and MMSE are optimal

explanations.a: Incorrect. ZF struggles with rank-deficient channels.
explanations.b: Incorrect. MMSE handles rank deficiency better due to regularization.
explanations.c: Correct. ZF becomes ill-conditioned and amplifies noise, degrading performance.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Neither is optimal in this case; MMSE is generally better.

questions.question: Which equalizer performs best in terms of Bit Error Rate (BER) in a noisy and ill-conditioned channel?

explanations.a: Incorrect. ZF performs poorly under noise and ill-conditioning.
explanations.b: Incorrect. MMSE is good but not optimal.
explanations.c: Correct. Maximum Likelihood Detection achieves the best BER performance but at higher complexity.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Matched Filter is not optimal for MIMO equalization.
